I'm a male and this seems typical.  Women may lose a little less. I haven't been doing much in the way of exercise as I fractured my leg just after starting the diet.When you come off the diet, you have flush your body of the HCG.  You do this by eating the same drinking & 500 cal diet for 3 more days while not getting the HCG.  Then you can eat anything you want as long as it doesn't have fats or carbs in it for 3 weeks AND you don't gain or lose more than 2 pounds going above your last lowest weight while on the drops.  Then for the next 3 weeks, you can slowly introduce fats and even more gradually carbs.  Inches and Pounds tells you what to do if you gain too much.   Follow it it works.It sounds to me like people haven't read the info and are gaining their weight back by going back to normal food right away.  Get the story straight and follow the plan -- read Inches and Pounds.  It does work.After I normalize my weight (after the six weeks) I'll decide if I want to do it once more (you have to wait between series) or if I'll go back to weight loss the more conventional way.Keep in mind that the reason you're doing this is to get rid of the fat cells not just make them smaller as in normal dieting.   And to reset your metabolism.   Afterwards, you have to adjust eating habits not to a diet but to a way of life.  Meaning that you give up eating more than you use, get away from fast food, restaurants and processed food, augment it with healthy liquid input (1/2 gallon a day is good) and exercise.IMHO - it works if you work the plan.  This is what I've found.Craig.

Concerning your entry on Jan. 26, I can tell you what might be happening. You probably figured it out, but I'll give it anyway. (I am an RN, by the way.) HCG is a hormone that is normally produced by women just after a fertilized egg has implanted in the lining of the uterus. Its job is to keep the endometrial lining intact until the placenta can produce enough estrogen to take over, then hCG production tapers off. In your case, I suspect that hCG is simply keeping the endometrial lining intact beyond when it would have normally disintegrated and discharged (menstruation). In this case it doesn't mean you are pregnant, but is giving you a "false positive" by preventing menstruation. Stopping the hCG treatments should result in resumption of your normal cycle. Timing your hCG diet plan to coordinate with your cycle would be better for your peace of mind but otherwise should not be a problem.Side note: Early detection pregnancy kits look for the presence of hCG in the blood or urine as a reliable indication of pregnancy, so obvioiusly if you are on the hCG diet that test will be void. It will give you a positive even if you are not pregnant.

There are a lot of comments on this particular thread that need clarification. SIde effects can be both negative (headaches) and positive (safe weight loss or hunger suppression). Many 'side effects' reported attributed to hCG during the protocol can be due to the low calorie intake, dehydration, the change to improved food choices, the body 'detoxifying' (the term is used loosely) because of the change to all organic foods, or a combination of the above. Of the many years hCG has been around there have been very few true long lasting negative side effects reported. And actually, none have been reported in decades that have been attributed specifically to the low dose hCG used in the protocol. Some of the things reported in this thread can be alleviated with increased water intake. Side note: drinking a few ozs of pure aloe vera juice/gel with each meal helps with bowel movements better than colace or other medications perscribed. Organic senna tea helps as well. A common side effect to this protocol is dry skin. This is usually temporary and improves on its own towards the end of the protocol. Again, using aloe vera gel helps and is a good skin conditioner but not the best moisturizer. Those of you who get headaches can use tylenol but if the headaches concern you or are unbearable or worse than you have ever experienced, stop the protocol and see your physician. You must be guided by a physician if you are going to utilize the hCG protocol. This is not for everybody.  --DrG

Anyone with existing renal (kidney) problems needs to see their primary physician to evaluate whether the hCG is appropriate. Not all renal problems are the same. As far as the hCG protocol being a direct cause for kidney problems I have not heard of any cases. However, if someone dehydrates themselves significantly or eliminates the fruits/veggies and just takes in high protein foods, the potential for kidney problems increase.To All: Hunger is a very subjective and complex issue. The hCG protocol does not "cure" hunger but allows for it's suppression in the normal setting. hunger can be triggered by so many things not related to your body requiring nutrition. It can be triggered by smell, sight, and emotional desires. Finding your individual triggers for hunger and minimizing those triggers is helpful. Also, some people are hungry only because they have trained their body to eat for the sake of eating at certain times of the day (or night) and for the sake of eatign certain things. Part of the learning with the protocol is the 'retraining' of your body to eat when it acutually needs the nutrition and to help your body to process foods more efficiently.

Just FYI for everyone:In looking into doing this myself, I bothered to actually look up the medical research on the subject (which is very easy to do...) and numerous clinical, double-blind trials prove that hCG has no more of an improved weight loss result than placebo. In other words, it's not the hCG, it's the diet. Further, there was no comparable difference in fat loss between hCG and placebo, and no comparable difference in feeling hungry between hCG and placebo. Listen, I value the idea of finding a great method that works, and understand and even agree with the idea that there may be some conspiracy or something preventing real weight loss drugs or methods being approved by the government, but it only takes a little bit to do the research yourself. Stop wasting money on the hCG and just go on the caloric restriction diet (taking vitamin supplements along with, of course). And of course, I'll finish with some links to the actual testing data:http://www.ajcn.org/cgi/reprint/29/9/940.pdfhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2405506?dopt=Abstracthttp://www.ajcn.org/cgi/reprint/26/2/211.pdfhttp://www.ajcn.org/cgi/reprint/14/3/133.pdfhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1237915/pdf/westjmed00268-0035.pdfhttp://archinte.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/137/2/151

While I do appreciate the post about the scientific research, I did educated myself and my 100+ friends, family and acquaintances did too. We are not a bunch of uninformed beanheads who ignored the studies. I myself found numerous problems with many of those clinical trials, as would anyone in the medical community with experience in clinical trials.Unfortunately, I have been on many diets that did not "work", that is...if I could have stuck with them, I may have had some weight loss, but I was either faint, irritable or had too many cravings to fight it. I have been on Releana for 10 days with a very low calorie diet. I have not been hungry, had any cravings, my mood is excellent, and as of this morning, I have lost 10.1 pounds.In those clinical trials, I cannot vouch for the type of hCG they used, where they procured it, the efficacy of their particular hCG, etc. I can only use my experience to describe my results.Yup, a VLCD will produce great results, if you can live through it, but that in itself is not an answer the the lifestyle change that goes along with taking hCG in the Simeons Pounds and Inches protocol, and most of the research has little to nothing to do with sublingual Releana. The VLCD is only one part of the success of Releana. It requires a lifestyle change, and give the blueprint to do it, while suppressing appetite and lifting mood. Everyone is different and must make their own choice. Personally, I don't see how anyone could have a viable opinion about Releana unless they tried it themselves. Of course, we can have opinions about things we don't try...it just makes them less credible. I didn't think it would work either. I was wrong. It does. I do not care if anyone thinks otherwise; now that I am doing it, I can tell you, it works for me. When I read posts from naysayers on this discussion board and others, I remember, I used to be one too. And I wouldn't take the opinion of anyone but myself now. I don't want to try to convince anyone of anything. I am only talking about my experience, and not theoretical or hypothetical or anything else data. I am constantly amazed at the negativity of people who haven't tried it and at the same time am amazed at the success of the 100+ people I know who it has worked for. Again...I am talking about Releana only, not homeopathic, not injectable, not the stuff from China or India available online. Appreciate the comments, but I know what I know, and do not see why anyone cares what I or anyone else is doing. I mean, it's my money, and my time, right? If I am a fool, then it isn't affecting anyone else, and at least I am speaking from personal experience. Why on earth would anyone else care what I wear, what I drive, what I watch on TV, or my method of dieting? I certainly am not affected by your choice of diet, and you aren't affected by mine. I am not wishing to sound angry here, and email is not effective at expressing mood, but just from a common sense viewpoint...if what I or anyone else does isn't affecting you, then why bother to post your negative and uninformed by personal experience view? It's pretty arrogant. But I do appreciate your passion, and if you do find an alternative that works this well, I hope you try it and report back, cos Releana is darned expensive! Thanks!

Hang in there girl.  The hunger will go away.  I found that (because I'm a grazer) it's best for me to have all my meals prepared ahead of time and that way I can eat a little here & there as I feel hungry.  There is no set order in which you have to eat the food they recommend.  I put meat on Melba Snacks and make myself little hor douvres.  When choosing fruit ... I choose the  largest I can find.  They recommend that as well. Then, I'll slice up the fruit, set it on a plate and nibble on that throughout the day.  9Be sure to try some of their recipes!!)  Since the HCG is utilizing body fat from my body, I usually don't get abnormally hungry.  That is how you can actually survive on the 500 CPD.  It's only for 21 days then you increase food intake to 1000CPD.  I've found that my face has cleared up, I feel more energetic during the day and sleep better at night.  The only side effect I have noted is dry skin.  Probably why my face cleared up. :)I'm using a homeopathic HCG, I wasn't comfortable with the injections from the doctors and I've lost a total of 20# in 3 wk.  This is even through Thanksgiving, which, admittedly, I was a very bad girl.  BUT ... I only went up 2 lbs and that came right back off when I returned to the diet.One important thing an exercise instructor stressed to me is that ... you should NOT exercise during the initial phase 1.  You are not consuming enough calories to support an exercise plan.  Wait until you've advanced to phase 2.  What's soooo cool about this is that it's homeopathic, once you've reached your goal weight and follow the instruction for resetting your Hypothalmus gland, you don't have to continue with the drops.  You will then maintain your weight with a regular healthy diet.  I've actually been able to stop taking my Thyroid medication, I no longer need it.  Now I'm waiting on Cholesterol & Triglyceride testing to come back.  Keeping my fingers crossed ... those have been my Albatross!But like I said ... keep your chin up ... find a HCG diet buddy, makes it more fun.  And remember to drink LOTS of water.  I have not been at my normal weight in 10 years ... I'm thrilled with the results.  This is where I get my product from and it's priced right:http://www.bathhousenaturals.comBest of luck to you ...
